title: Multiple OpenSSL error handling issues in nodejs crypto library
vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** NodeJS up to 19.2.0 does not clear the OpenSSL error stack after operations that may set it

**Description:** NodeJS up to 19.2.0 does not clear the OpenSSL error stack after operations that may set it. This may lead to false positive errors during subsequent cryptographic operations that happen to be on the same thread.

## Steps To Reproduce:

The following issues have reproduction cases:

https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/45495
https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/45377

Upon reviewing the code in crypto_x509.cc, at least one other function lacks use of ClearErrorOnReturn - X509Certificate::CheckPrivateKey.

https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/main/src/crypto/crypto_x509.cc#L432

## Impact:

On our application, JWTs failed to sign after a certificate fails to verify on the same thread.

## Impact

If the server verifies certificates using Node's X509Certificate API, it may fail to sign other users' auth tokens: if a certificate fails to verify, the error from the previous failing call is applied to the next call that should succeed. It is worth auditing all OpenSSL entry points to see if they can cause errors to be raised.

activities.message:
My mistake - I meant **X509Certificate::CheckIssued** for the likely other bugged function. This codepath is potentially in the stack:

https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/a275afc527d05b5187b457bdbcd0e1dcb18839f1/crypto/x509/v3_purp.c#L444
That function is also in the stack of X509Certificate::CheckCA (which also lacks a ClearErrorOnReturn), so this can also be triggered by checking that a malformed cert is a CA cert .
Thanks for reporting! Could you clarify how an attacker could be exploiting this? There does not seem to be any impact on confidentiality, integrity or availability.

Sure. Take a web service where a user can sign in which also processes certificate uploads from users.

- Alice uploads a certificate that fails to verify or parse and triggers something to be pushed onto the OpenSSL error queue.
- Bob attempts to sign in, and Bob's request is made on the same thread as Alice. Signing fails due to the entry previously pushed onto the error queue by Alice. Therefore, the service is unavailable to Bob if Alice continues uploading invalid certificates.

Simple proof of concept attached that works on node 19.2 and prevents signing using a key based on a prior certificate's failure to verify:

```
[nix-shell:~/poc]$ node poc.js
Cert is a CA: false
node:internal/crypto/sig:131
  const ret = this[kHandle].sign(data, format, type, passphrase, rsaPadding,
                            ^

Error: error:0580009E:x509 certificate routines::reason(158)
    at Sign.sign (node:internal/crypto/sig:131:29)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/mjones/poc/poc.js:68:26)
    at Module._compile (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1218:14)
    at Module._extensions..js (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1272:10)
    at Module.load (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1081:32)
    at Module._load (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:922:12)
    at Function.executeUserEntryPoint [as runMain] (node:internal/modules/run_main:82:12)
    at node:internal/main/run_main_module:23:47 {
  library: 'x509 certificate routines'
}

Node.js v19.2.0
```

{F2080405}

I can reproduce your example using Node.js v19.2.0 but not v18.12.1 and v16.17.0. In other terms, the affected versions are only in the range (v19.0.0 - v19.2.0).
Could you confirm?

Triaging as a vulnerability we accept and will fix
Based on the [threat model](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/main/SECURITY.md#the-nodejs-threat-model)
> Any unexpected behavior from the data manipulation from Node.js Internal functions are considered a vulnerability.
If I understand this is already fixed in v19.3.0.

```

  node: '16.18.1',
  v8: '9.4.146.26-node.22',
  uv: '1.44.2',
  zlib: '1.2.13',
  brotli: '1.0.9',
  ares: '1.18.1',
  modules: '93',
  nghttp2: '1.47.0',
  napi: '8',
  llhttp: '6.0.10',
  openssl: '3.0.7',
  cldr: '42.0',
  icu: '72.1',
  tz: '2022e',
  unicode: '15.0'

```

We have seen this behavior with OpenSSL 1.1 on the affected versions of Node too.
Based on https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/v19.3.0/src/crypto/crypto_x509.cc#L341 19.3.0 should still be vulnerable because X509Certificate::CheckCA does not include a ClearErrorOnReturn instance.

I may have misspoken:

We saw X509Certificate::Verify causing problems in 18.12.1 with OpenSSL 1.1. If I downgrade to OpenSSL 1.1 using the [nix package](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/nixos-unstable/pkgs/development/web/nodejs/v16.nix#L11), it does behave better on the isCA check in the PoC. It seems like OpenSSL 3 created more failure paths for these functions that could push something onto the error stack.

```
[nix-shell:~/poc]$ node poc.js
{
  node: '16.18.1',
  v8: '9.4.146.26-node.22',
  uv: '1.44.2',
  zlib: '1.2.13',
  brotli: '1.0.9',
  ares: '1.18.1',
  modules: '93',
  nghttp2: '1.47.0',
  napi: '8',
  llhttp: '6.0.10',
  openssl: '1.1.1s',
  cldr: '42.0',
  icu: '72.1',
  tz: '2022e',
  unicode: '15.0'
}
Cert is a CA: false
Signature: 
```

I'm ultimately not sure what the scope of affected releases is, since it seems that Node 19.2 included some fixes, but still doesn't fix the isCA issue. So we probably need something more comprehensive that addresses all cases here.

My understanding is that:

1. Node.js v16.x is not vulnerable
2. Node.js v18.x is vulnerable
3. Node.js v19.0.0 < 19.2.0 was vulnerable, 19.2.0 contains the fix

Please confirm.

1. Node.js v16.x is not vulnerable: Incorrect. See above.
2. Node.js v18.x is vulnerable. Correct.
3. Node.js v19.0.0 < 19.2.0 was vulnerable, 19.2.0 contains the fix. Incorrect.

There are at least two separate vulnerabilities here with the same cause. 19.2.0 and 19.3.0 do **not** contain the fix as there is no ClearErrorOnReturn used for CheckCA, nor is there for several other calls. This vulnerability seems to be aggravated by OpenSSL 3.0 causing more use of the error queue.

19.2.0 contains the fix for [X509Certificate::Verify](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/45377) and [X509Certificate::CheckPrivateKey](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/45495) which can occur with OpenSSL 1.1 and OpenSSL 3.0.

There may be other vulnerabilities related to ignoring the existence of the OpenSSL error queue that are not mentioned here.

I used the poc linked in https://hackerone.com/reports/1808596#activity-19605997 to verify.

Please include pocs for all vulnerabilities.

Two more pocs that break on versions of node <19.2.0 per these issues:

https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/45495
https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/45377

{F2088562} {F2088564}
Thanks!

No problem - there are certainly other ways to trigger this, such as CheckIssued instead of isCA.

Another PoC that exploits a cert with negative path length on OpenSSL 3: {F2089850}

Hi @mjones-vsat 

Are you able to reproduce this behavior using CheckHost, CheckIP, and CheckEmail? As you mentioned previously, those methods may have the same behavior, but I couldn't reproduce it locally.
I'll give it a try, just ramping back up on this after the holidays.

Thanks, @mjones-vsat. The fix is under review, pretty soon we'll build the binary and send it to you to confirm all these behaviors were addressed. Could you please share your operating system + architecture?
NixOS / x86_64. I'll have to patchelf any prebuilds, could you just send me a git patch instead and I'll build?
Also, I've been on vacation recently but there are probably a handful more proofs of concept I'll try, likely by next week. Thanks for taking this issue seriously.
Additionally, I meant to ask: can we get a CVE pulled for this?
Sure, we will assign one right before release.

@mjones-vsat This doesn't affect Node.js v16 or prior, right? Also, can you validate that the patch attached fixes this report?
{F2127007}

>This doesn't affect Node.js v16 or prior, right?

This poc does: https://hackerone.com/bugs?report_id=1808596&subject=user#activity-19605997

>Also, can you validate that the patch attached fixes this report?

Validated on node 18; the patch fails to apply on node 16.
@mike-myers-tob Thanks! I couldn't reproduce it on v14. The v16 patch is attached, could you please validate it?{F2128889}
I think it would be minimum v15 since that's when the X509Certificate APIs were added. I'll test the v16 patch against my pocs.
v15 is currently end-of-life. We don't support it anymore. The current active releases are v14, v16, v18, and v19.

BTW, nix-shell invocations like the above may help with testing. You get an isolated nodejs linked against OpenSSL 3. It's how I've been running my validations and should produce the same result barring differences in nixpkgs version.

No failures I can see.

Sure. "Thank you, to Morgan Jones from Viasat Secure Mobile for reporting this vulnerability."

Can we have an update on release timeline?

Update on the credit:

In latest security release - https://nodejs.org/en/blog/vulnerability/february-2023-security-releases/

Just because it was fun:

A proof of concept that used Express and the OpenSSL error queue as a covert channel (think a serial line).

The protocol is simple, if we get a 200, it's a 0. If we get a 500, it's a 1. We can transmit ASCII text at 15 baud using some rudimentary error correction.

Usage:

```
$ nix-shell -p nodejs_16-x
$ node poc-express.js &
$ cat beemovie.txt | node poc-tx.js &>/dev/null &
$ node poc-rx.js
```

```
$ cat beemovie.txt  | node poc-tx.js
According to all known laws of aviation, there is no way a bee should be able to fly.
Its wings are too small to get its fat little body off the ground.
The bee, of course, flies anyway because bees don't care what humans think is impossible.
Yellow, black. Yellow, black. Yellow, black. Yellow, black.
Ooh, black and yellow!
Let's shake it up a little.
Barry! Breakfast is ready!
Coming!
Hang on a second.
Hello?
Barry?
Adam?
Can you believe this is happening?
I can't.
I'll pick you up.
Looking sharp.
Use the stairs, Your father paid good money for those.
Sorry. I'm excited.
Here's the graduate.
We're very proud of you, son.
A perfect report card, all B's.
Very proud.
Ma! I got a thing going here.
You got lint on your fuzz.
Ow! That's me!
Wave to us! We'll be in row 118,000.
Bye!
Barry, I told you, stop flying in the house!
Hey, Adam.
Hey, Barry.
Is that fuzz gel?
A little. Special day, graduation.
```
